Award.AwardTitle: EXTREEMS-QED: Large Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Iowa
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are to modernize and integrate the undergraduate and graduate curricula in the three Departments of Mathematics, Statistics, and Computer Science so as to better prepare undergraduate students to study and work effectively in the information age, and to foster research collaboration among faculty and undergraduate students across disciplinary lines within and beyond the quantitative sciences. The prospective new degree in Data Science will be crowned by a capstone course that will contain research projects involving scientifically important problems and use the latest Big Data techniques.

The holders of the new degree will be capable to work on problems at the frontiers of science that require the integration of large-scale simulation of partial differential equations and other mathematical constructs, data capture and statistical analysis, and high performance computing to provide accurate, reliable, and useful forecasts and descriptions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EXTREEMS-QED award for Large Data Analysis led first to the creation of a new Certificate for undergraduates at the University of Iowa in Large Data Analysis. This Certificate began in 2015 until 2019 when it was discbanded by the University of Iowa. In its place is a new major in Data Science that is administered jointly by the Departments of Computer Science and Statistics and Actuarial Sciences. A total of 29 students graduated with the Certificate during this period.

All the students taking the Certificate took a capstone course Large Data Analysis taught by the Certificate team. This course emphasized project work to enable students to see how these methods can be applied to practical problems. These projects were also group projects, which reflects the work environment they will find when they join the workforce, bringing their knowledge and skills with them.

To encourage interest in Large Data Analysis and related topics, the principal investigators also created a Big Data Summer School, held at the University of Iowa during the summers of 2015 to 2018. These summer schools were open to incoming first year and finishing first year students. These summer schools introduced students to important ideas of probability and statistics, machine learning, and computing through talks by practitioners of data science at the University of Iowa and hands-on activities.

Finally, a number of individual students in the Certificate program participated in research activities with the principal investigators. This lead to the development of software and instructional videos, and also academic papers pushing the boundaries of current knowledge. These research projects were on topics including topological data analysis, use of statistical analysis software, gerrymandering and electoral subdivisions, and recommender systems.
